Line 5: Line 5:  
Love might best defined as acting intentionally, in response to others (including God), to promote overall well-being (Oord). In this, love has a degree of freedom and this freedom is expressed in relation to others in the effort to promote the common good.
 
Love might best defined as acting intentionally, in response to others (including God), to promote overall well-being (Oord). In this, love has a degree of freedom and this freedom is expressed in relation to others in the effort to promote the common good.
    −
Just as there are many types of lovers, there are many kinds of love. Love is inherent in all human cultures. It is precisely these cultural differences that make any universal definition of love difficult to establish. See the [[Sapir-Whorf hypothesis]].
+
Love can also essentially be defined as the decision to make an unconditional commitment to giving yourself to an other. For the best example of this kind of love, see Shel Silverstein's [[The Giving Tree]]. This idea of love encompasses all the distinctions that human civilization has made, as enumerated two paragraphs below. This definition of love is also known to have been watered down into "types" or "categories" because of a perpetual confusion of love with emotion, affection, and, in particular, desire. But essentially, it is a choice.
  +   +
Love is inherent in all human cultures. It is precisely these cultural differences that make any universal definition of love difficult to establish. See the [[Sapir-Whorf hypothesis]].
     
Expressions of love may include the love for a [[soul]] or mind, the love of laws and organizations, love for a body, love for nature, love of food, love of money, love for learning, love of power, love of fame, love for the respect of others, et cetera. Different people place varying degrees of importance on the kinds of love they receive. Love is essentially an abstract concept, easier to experience than to explain.

Different people place varying degrees of importance on the kinds of love they receive. Love is essentially an abstract concept, easier to experience than to explain.
